subtitle: Did you know that the biblical Moses was not only a real historical figure,
but also the adopted son of the revered pharaoh, Thothmes III? Additionally,
an Anunnaki being of the tribe of Enlil, known as the God of Israel, masqueraded as
the creator of all and commanded Moses to lead the Israelites out of enslavement in Egypt and used
advanced extraterrestrial technology to plague Egypt. However, in their quest for a new land,
the Israelites' descendants of Abraham were instructed to conquer the lands
of their ancestral cousins, the polytheistic Canaanites, who are modern-day Palestinians,
turning these once-allied tribes into enemies for the establishment of the Holy Land, Israel.
The ancient Jewish historian Josephus adjusted the writings of the Egyptian historian Manetho,
who originally recorded that Moses was the adopted brother of Amenhotep II, the son of Thothmes III.
It was Thothmes, not Rameses II, who ruled right before the biblical exodus in the Bible. Manetho,
in his historical account of the pharaohs of the 18th dynasty, referred to the pharaoh who
expelled the pastoral people from Egypt. This likely references the historical
expulsion of the Hyksos, the Asiatic non-Semitic shepherd kings, in 1567 BC by the 18th dynasty.
This line of colonizing, enslaving Afro-Asian rulers began with pharaoh Thothmes I and
continued for generations, and included the famous pharaoh Akhenaten. During this time,
the pyramid wars among the Anunnaki extraterrestrial tribes were at their
peak. The factions of Enlil and Enki manipulated humanity by masquerading as gods, using them
as pawns to seize control of lands and people, fostering division and tribalism among mankind.
The god of Israel, Yahweh, who belonged to Enlil's tribe, and the god of Egypt,
Amun-Ra, influenced the Kushite pharaohs of the 18th dynasty to wage war, enslave,
and oppress the Israelites. Advanced technological weapons were deployed by both sides, igniting wars
between gods and humans, fought on land and in the skies. In the golden age of Egypt's new kingdom,
a man raised as a prince, yet born a slave. His name was Moses. Born to Hebrew parents
during the reign of the powerful pharaoh Thothmes I, an Egyptian Kushite pharaoh often compared to
an ancient Napoleon-like figure, Moses' life began under the shadow of danger. Thothmes I,
fearing the growing numbers and potential rebellion of the enslaved Israelites,
had decreed the death of all Hebrew male infants. But Moses' mother, with desperate faith,
placed her infant son in a reed basket, setting him adrift on the Nile. The currents of fate
guided the basket into the hands of none other than Pharaoh's daughter Hatshepsut,
who, childless herself, claimed the boy as her own. She named him Moses, meaning drawn from the
water, and raised him as royal son of Pharaoh Thothmes III within the grand palaces of Egypt.
Moses grew up in the palace of Pharaoh, surrounded by wealth,
power, and the luxuries of royal Egyptian life. Adopted by the great queen Hatshepsut, the eldest
daughter of Pharaoh Thothmes I, Moses was raised as a prince alongside his brother Amenhotep II,
also known as Amais. From the moment they could walk, the two young princes were inseparable.
They raced chariots through the bustling streets of Thebes, played pranks on their tutors,
and together explored the wonders of the palace. Amenhotep II would be the future ruler of Egypt,
admired Moses, who, though born a slave, carried himself with the regal bearing of
a pharaoh Thothmes' son. Their bond was one of brotherhood, forged in laughter and competition.
As heirs to the greatest empire on earth, the brothers were groomed for leadership,
and yet it was Moses who often shined more brightly. Amenhotep, in his heart, longed
for his father's approval, struggling under the weight of expectation. His father, Thothmes III,
Egypt's greatest warrior-king, had led grand military campaigns across Canaan, Sudan, and into
the far reaches of the Sumerian Mesopotamia, which was beginning its decline, creating an empire
that rivaled any other in the ancient world. Thothmes expected his eldest son to continue
this legacy. However, their idyllic brotherhood began to unravel as Moses grew older and became
more aware of the cruel realities of Egyptian rule. Moses grew up amid the splendor of
Egypt's elite, unaware of his true origins. He learned in the ways of the pharaohs,
trained in the arts of war, and schooled in the wisdom of Egypt. Yet as he matured, whispers
of his lineage reached his ears, and he could no longer ignore the signs. His Hebrew features, his
sympathy for the laboring slaves, and a growing restlessness led him to question who he truly was.
While Amenhotep, blinded by his loyalty to the kingdom and his desire to please their father,
saw the enslavement of the Israelites as necessary for the glory of Egypt, Moses began to notice the
suffering of the Hebrew people. Whispers about his true origins had always lingered in the palace,
but Moses had ignored them, until one fateful day when he came face to face with the brutal
oppression his people endured. One fateful day, witnessing an Egyptian taskmaster brutally
beating a Hebrew slave, Moses' blood boiled. In a fit of rage, he struck the Egyptian dead,
burying him in the sand. Word of his crime spread quickly, and Moses knew his life in Egypt was
over. He fled into the wilderness, escaping the death sentence of Pharaoh Thothmes III.
Torn between two worlds, Moses could no longer remain in the palace. His guilt
and the fear of being exposed drove him to flee the only life he had ever known. Emmaus,
also known as Pharaoh Amenhotep II, was devastated by the sudden disappearance of his brother.
To Emmaus, Moses' flight was not just an act of rebellion against the kingdom,
but a personal abandonment. Their once unbreakable bond was shattered. According to Exodus,
Moses wandered into the wilderness of Sinai. Moses found himself once again standing before
an act of injustice, compelled to intervene. This time, it was Zipporah and her sisters,
tending to their flocks of sheep, who were being driven away by a group of men. Without hesitation,
Moses stepped in to defend them, fending off the men and allowing the women to water their sheep.
Grateful for his courage, the young women brought Moses back to their father, Jethro,
the priest of Midian. The Midianites were a nomadic tribe of dark, melanated Arabs. To the
eye, they were sometimes confused as Kushites. However, they were not. This tribe, however,
did worship the god Yahweh of Abraham. Seeing Moses as a worthy match for his daughter, Jethro
decided that Zipporah and Moses should marry. While it might seem that Moses married beneath
him, the reality was more complex. The Hebrews, enslaved under Egyptian rule, were the true
underdogs in society, as noted by the authors of Misreading Scripture with Western Eyes. In the
ancient kingdoms of Egypt, Hebrews were considered a slave race, much as certain groups were viewed
through a biased lens in other cultures. Zipporah and her sisters, upon meeting Moses,
believed him to be Egyptian, likely due to his mannerisms and Coptic accent. An
Egyptian rescued us from the shepherds, they told their father Jethro. Whether
Moses corrected them immediately is left unsaid in the text, but their initial impression of him
as Egyptian may have worked to his advantage. Though Moses had been raised in the Egyptian
royal household, he was not of royal blood, merely an adopted son. Unlike Egyptian royalty, who often
married within the family, Moses had to find a suitable match elsewhere. In Midian, it seemed,
Moses decided it was time to settle down. His single status, unusual in Egypt where
marriage after puberty was customary, likely made him an oddity to the Midianites. Yet here,
in this foreign land, he found a new beginning with Zipporah. For years,
he lived a life of quiet obscurity, finding peace in the simplicity of the desert, but the memories
of Egypt and his adopted brother haunted him. Then, one day, as he tended his flock near
Mount Sinai, Moses encountered something miraculous to his ancient eye and knowledge,
a bush burning with fire, yet not consumed. This burning bush that Moses interacted with
was most likely a pyrocommunication interface, which combines an ember net system simulation
with communication technology. From within the device, the voice of Yahweh called out to him.
Yahweh, at this time period, was an Anunnaki extraterrestrial prince named Ninurta,
who served under the title of Yahweh from his father and predecessor Enlil. Yahweh then called
out to Moses from the bush, saying, Moses, Moses, and Moses responded, Here I am. Yahweh then said,
Take off your sandals, for the place where you are standing is holy ground.
He continued, I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac,
and the God of Jacob. Yahweh then said, I have indeed seen the misery of my people in Egypt. I
have heard them crying out because of their slave drivers, and I am concerned about their suffering.
So I have come down to rescue them from the hand of the Egyptians, and to bring them up
out of that land into a good and spacious land, a land flowing with milk and with honey, the home
of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites. Yahweh then continued, And
now the cry of the Israelites has reached me, and I have seen the way the Egyptians are oppressing
them. So now, go, I am sending you to Pharaoh to bring my people the Israelites out of Egypt.
As Moses journeyed back to Egypt, preparing to fulfill his divine mission and confront
Pharaoh, Yahweh, the very God who had chosen him to lead the Israelites to freedom,
now appeared intent on ending Moses' life. The reason for this divine wrath was unclear at first,
but the moment was tense, filled with an urgency Moses could not escape, and was in
the midst of dying from disease. Moses' wife, Zipporah, sensed the gravity of the situation.
Though she may not have fully understood Yahweh's ways, she acted quickly. In a swift motion, she
grabbed a flint knife and circumcised their son, Gershom. With precision,
she took the bloody foreskin and touched it to Moses' feet, speaking the words,
Surely you are a bridegroom of blood to me. Her actions were not merely out of fear,
they were a desperate attempt to protect her husband and ensure his survival in the
face of divine anger. As soon as the ritual was complete, Yahweh relented, sparing Moses' life.
In that instant, it became clear. Moses had neglected a sacred duty,
a responsibility tied to the ancient covenant between Yahweh and Abraham, the covenant of
circumcision. The act of circumcision was more than a ritual, it was a symbol of belonging to
God's chosen people, a mark that every Hebrew male must bear. It's easy to overlook the fact
that Moses was raised in an Egyptian household, surrounded by Egyptian gods and goddesses.
It's possible he wasn't circumcised. As scholar Michael Heiser points out, had the boy been marked
by Hebrew circumcision, his life would likely have been at risk in Pharaoh's household. Moses,
the man chosen to lead the Hebrews out of slavery, had not upheld this covenant with his own son.
And for a mission of such significance, no detail could be overlooked by Yahweh,
no law could be ignored. Zipporah's decisive act not only saved her husband, but also reaffirmed
the covenant, reminding Moses of the weight of his role. Though she was not an Israelite
by birth, her understanding of what was required in that moment was profound.
With her intervention, Moses' path was restored, and he could continue
his journey to Egypt. By the time Moses returned to Egypt, Thothmes III had passed,
and his son Amenhotep II ruled the land. According to historical sources, Amenhotep may have been the
pharaoh referred to by Theophilus as Amasis. Amenhotep II was a fierce and proud pharaoh,
much like his father, known for his brutal suppression of enemies and his military
prowess. It was before this pharaoh that Moses stood, now a prophet of Yahweh, and demanded,
let my people go. The once beloved brothers now stood on opposite sides of a great divide.
Their reunion was bittersweet. Amenhotep, joyful to see his long-lost brother,
hoped Moses had returned to take his place at his side. But Moses had come with a message that
would challenge Amai's very identity and rule. Let my people go. Amenhotep, still burdened by
the expectations of their father, and now the ruler of the most powerful kingdom on earth,
could not fathom letting the Israelites leave. To him, Moses' request was a threat
of not only the kingdom and his family's reign, but everything they had once shared.
The two brothers clashed, not just in words, but in their beliefs. Moses, driven by his
newfound faith in Yahweh and Amenhotep, bound by his loyalty to the Anunnaki gods of Egypt,
who were of Enki's tribe with Amun-Ra at the helm, and the legacy of their father, found themselves
at an impasse. Amai's, who had once sought Moses' approval, now saw him as an enemy, yet deep
within, the bond of brotherhood still lingered, clouding his judgment and hardening his heart.
Inanna and Minota together unleashed technological plagues upon Egypt through
a pathogen dissemination system and powerful biohazard generators enough to facilitate viral
agents and widespread disease outbreaks. Moses told Amenhotep that his one god was
more powerful than their Egyptian gods. One by one, the Nile turned to blood,
frogs overran the land, lice and flies tormented the people, and disease ravaged the livestock.
Despite the devastation, Amenhotep's pride would not allow him to yield. He could not accept that
the brother he once loved had now become his adversary. During the time of Moses, Amun-Ra,
also known as Marduk, the extraterrestrial son of Enki, was entombed alive within the
Great Pyramid by Inanna and Minota, rendering him powerless to assist in Egypt's salvation.
While he had air to breathe, he was deprived of food and water, left to endure a slow,
agonizing death in isolation. As the plagues ravaged Egypt, the final and most devastating
blow was engineered once again by the Anunnaki tribe of Enlil, the death of every first-born
Egyptian. In a single night, the tribe of Enlil swept through the land of Egypt,
claiming the lives of all first-born sons, from the humblest slave to the Pharaoh's own child.
Overcome with grief after the loss of his son, Pharaoh Amenhotep was broken. How can your God
be so powerful, he asked, shattered by the tragedy? In his despair, he finally relented,
granting Moses, his once beloved brother, the freedom he sought for the Israelites, his people.
Even some Egyptians, disillusioned and grieving, left their homes to join Moses and his people in
their exodus from Egypt, which at this point in time was not the largest migration from Egypt.
It's important to note that both the Egyptians and Israelites during this time were multiracial and
multicultural Afro-Asiatics. With haste, Moses led the Hebrews out of Egypt, the
beginnings of their journey toward the Promised Land. But once again, Amenhotep pride surged,
and he could not let go of the idea that he had been bested by Moses like when they were children.
He then thought of his father Thothmes and his god Amun-Ra and regretted his decision.
He chased the Israelites with his Egyptian guard, driving them toward the Reed Sea, distinct from
the great Red Sea. Here, they crossed through the shallow waters of the Reed Sea, a unique
body of water where the terrain shifted. Earlier in the day, it would lower,
creating an easier path to walk across, but by nightfall, the water level would rise again.
The Israelites' crossing was directed by Yahweh from his flying black ship,
the ship of Ninurta. As Emmaus and his forces followed, the waters crashed back down, drowning
the Pharaoh himself and the Pharaoh's soldiers. In that moment, Moses' journey from prince to
prophet was complete. He had freed his people, but the cost had been great. In
the arid wilderness of the Sinai Peninsula, the Israelites wandered for 40 long years,
led by Moses, their prophet and leader. After their miraculous escape from slavery in
Egypt, marked by the parting of the Red Sea, they found themselves in a vast desert. The journey to
the Promised Land, the land of milk and honey as God had promised, was fraught with hardship,
hunger, and doubt. As the Israelites marched through the scorching desert,
they began to grumble against Moses and Aaron. Their provisions were running low, and they
feared starvation. In their despair, they cried out, longing for the bread and meat they had left
behind in Egypt. Moses turned to the God of Israel in prayer, and the Lord God Yahweh, also known as
Ninurta or his father Enlil, answered by sending a food source known as manna, a nourishing food
that appeared on the ground each morning like dew. This manna, described as fine flakes like frost,
sustained the Israelites during their long journey. However,
there was more to their sustenance than met the eye. According to ancient texts, God or
Yahweh provided the Israelites with a divine machine, a celestial device known as the Omer,
which processed and distributed the manna food. This machine was said to have descended from
heaven, constructed by the hand of God or his angels. However,
this technology would be known today as a sustenance generator or nutrient dispenser,
highly powerful and advanced food generator. Its purpose was to feed the Exodus group in
the desert while they waited for a new land. Each morning, the Omer would supply manna to
the people in measured portions. The machine was a marvel, never running out of manna and
ensuring that the Israelites had enough food to survive, yet not more than what
they needed for the day. They were instructed to gather only enough for their families,
and any excess would spoil overnight, except on the Sabbath, when a double portion was provided,
so they could rest on the holy day. As the Israelites journeyed deeper
into the wilderness, they arrived at the base of Mount Sinai. Here, Ninurta and the tribe of Enlil
would make a covenant with the Israelites. It was then Yahweh called to Moses, ascend the mountain
of Sinai, disappearing into the thick cloud of smoke and fire that enveloped the summit.
Once atop the mountain, Moses entered the cloud and stood in the physical presence of Yahweh.
His body glowed of a reddish brilliance. This moment was both terrifying and awe-inspiring.
Yahweh spoke to Moses directly, establishing a profound relationship characterized by intimacy
and authority. Yahweh began by reiterating his identity as the Lord God who brought the
Israelites out of Egypt, emphasizing his covenant and alliance with them. Yahweh,
also known as Ninurta, or sometimes by his father Enlil, instructed Moses to relay to the people
the importance of obedience to their commands. Yahweh provided Moses with the Ten Commandments,
inscribing them on two stone tablets. These commandments were foundational ethical laws
intended to guide the moral behavior of the Israelites. God spoke them aloud,
each commandment establishing clear principles for living in harmony with him and with one another.
The commandments were not just rules but a divine contract between the Lord God Yahweh and his
chosen people. They set the boundaries for a holy life, centered around the worship of Yahweh only,
and detailed ethical laws governing everything from relationships to societal justice.
While Moses was atop the mountain, the people became impatient and fearful.
Fearing abandonment and unsure of their future, they turned to Aaron,
demanding a tangible God to worship. Influenced by their recent experiences in Egypt, where idol
worship was common, Aaron succumbed to their pressure and crafted a golden calf, believing
it would provide a familiar representation of This decision reflected a misguided compromise,
as Aaron likely intended to create a symbol for the people while still honoring Yahweh. However,
the act of making an idol directly violated the commandments that Moses was receiving.
As the Israelites began to revel in their worship of the calf, the situation escalated. When Moses
descended the mountain and witnessed their idolatry, he was filled with rage and broke the
tablets inscribed with Yahweh's laws. The incident highlighted the Israelites' failure of faith and
loyalty, leading to severe consequences from God. In the end, Moses pleaded for mercy, resulting in
a renewed covenant between God and his people, serving as a powerful reminder of the dangers of
idolatry and the importance of steadfast faith in times of uncertainty. After pleading with Yahweh
for mercy on behalf of the Israelites, he ascended the mountain again and returned with new tablets,
restoring the covenant. Despite their miraculous sustenance, the Israelites
struggled with doubt and disobedience as punishment for their lack of faith.
Yahweh, the God of Israel, decreed that they would wander the wilderness for 40 years,
a full generation, before entering the Promised Land. Only after this time would
they be allowed to claim the land flowing with milk and honey. Throughout these years,
the divine sustenance generator continued to provide, feeding them daily with manna.
Moses, though he had led them through the wilderness and served as a mediator between
the people and God, was informed that he would not enter the Promised Land. Because of a moment
of disobedience, when he struck a rock to bring forth water instead of speaking to it as God
had commanded, Moses was only allowed to see the land from a distance. As the years passed
and the generation of the first Exodus faded away, Joshua, Moses' faithful aid and warrior,
was chosen to succeed him. When Moses died on Mount Nebo,
overlooking the Promised Land, Joshua assumed leadership of the Israelites. His task was to
lead the people across the Jordan River and into the land of Canaanites, an Asiatic group of nomad,
descendants and tribes of Cain. The Canaanites, with their diverse city-states and tribes,
had established a vibrant society long before the arrival of the Israelites,
who were the descendants of Abraham's tribe. They spoke various dialects of Semitic languages
and practiced polytheism, worshipping a pantheon of deities, including Baal and Asherah. Joshua
was a strong warrior and under his command, the Israelites began their conquest of the
land. Yahweh promised Joshua victory, telling him to be strong and courageous.
The first major city they encountered was Jericho, an imposing city with high fortified walls. Yahweh
gave Joshua specific instructions to march around the city for six days with the Ark of
the Covenant, and on the seventh day they were to march seven times. At the sound of trumpets
and a loud shout, the walls of Jericho miraculously crumbled, and the Israelites
stormed the city, taking it as their own. This conquest marked the beginning of a new
chapter for the Israelites as they moved from wandering to settling. City by city,
Joshua led the people, and the God of Israel delivered the enemy tribes into their hands.
They took possession of their land that the God of Israel had promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
Tiki Israelites' journey from Egypt to the Promised Land was a testament to early humanity's
struggles, and the Anunnaki tribes battling amongst each other, masquerading as gods,
making mankind fight amongst each other. The machine that provided manna, the divine laws
given at Sinai, and the miraculous victories under Joshua were all signs of the tribe of Enlil's
provision and care for their chosen people. Thus the era of wandering ended,
and the era of settlement began, a fulfillment of Yahweh's ancient promise to lead his people to a
where they would live in peace and prosperity. The exodus, traditionally dated to 1433 BC, when
Moses was 80 years old, marked the culmination of a centuries-long saga of oppression, rebellion,
and divine intervention. The pharaoh Amenhotep II, like his predecessors, had sought to suppress
the growing power of the Israelites, yet in doing so he only hastened their people. From
the time of Ammoses, who expelled the Hyksos and founded the New Kingdom, to Thutmose III,
who feared the Israelites' disloyalty, and finally to Amenhotep II, who saw his empire
suffer under Yahweh's plagues, the tale of Egypt and Israel became one of intertwined destinies,
shaped by the hand of God and the will of man. The story of Moses, his confrontation with
pharaoh Amenhotep II, and the dramatic exodus from Egypt, has long been revered as one of
the most iconic tales of faith, liberation, and divine intervention in human history. However,
as we delve deeper into ancient texts with a broader, more informed perspective,
it's essential to reconsider the narrative through the lens of the Anunnaki. These ancient beings,
often mistaken for gods due to their advanced technology and knowledge, greatly
influenced the writings of both the Old and New Testaments, pitting humanity against one another.
The Anunnaki were not divine beings, but their technological prowess was so far beyond the
comprehension of early humans that biblical figures perceived them as gods or messengers
of God. Yet, the true creator of all existence, the ultimate source of life and consciousness,
remains distinct from these extraterrestrial beings who, for centuries, masqueraded as divine
creators on earth. Their influence shaped much of the biblical lore, manipulating the spiritual
narrative of entire civilizations, especially the animosity and rivalry of African and the Asiatics,
the first races of humans, and after the Asiatics' rivalry between the Israelites and the Canaanites.
Later, more deception was compounded by the elites within the Vatican and the Cabal after
the crucifixion of Yeshua, who systematically engineered religious doctrines and designed
to mentally enslave societies and create divide-and-conquer tactics of the Twelve
Tribes. These institutions diverted spiritual power away from individuals and toward an
extraterrestrial elite, fostering systems of control that suppressed true self-empowerment.
In this light, the story of Moses and the biblical text becomes not just a tale of faith,
but a key to understanding humanity's deeper connection to a much larger cosmic history.
